item.title: secretProject part 3 - http.HandleFunc in Go
item.description: Oh, what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive!!. -Sir Walter Scott Previously on codedinsugar.com Now that we have our secretProject Kubernetes cluster built, let’s throw some custom apps in there! Keep it simple and sweet This is NOT a Kubernetes (k8s) tutorial! The k8s ecosystem is massive if you’re into container orchestration, read their docs here. I use k8s everyday at work and at home and even though it’s almost become second nature for me, I still don’t know everything about it…

item.title: secretProject part 2 - fun with Ansible
item.description: Mr. Wizard! Get me the hell out of here!. -Neo Previously on codedinsugar.com Continuing where we left off, we’ve used libvirt/virt-install to successfully create three vm’s for our Kubernetes cluster for secretProject. So what happens next? Let’s play with Ansible I’ve used Ansible often in the past but it was never a core part of my daily work. There is a lot to learn about Ansible and I highly suggest you check out their site, especially if you’re interested in the SRE/DevOps space.

item.title: secretProject part 1 - fun with KVM
item.description: Unfortunately, no one can be told what the Matrix is. You have to see it for yourself. -Morpheus Previously on codedinsugar.com Continuing where we left off, I wanted to build a kvm vm’s to run a Kubernetes cluster for the secretProject platform. Since the early 2000’s I’ve used several virtualization hypervisors, including: Hyper-V KVM VMware VirtualBox XenServer Not including AWS EC2 and Docker But for the purpose of secretProject and the need to self-host on a single bare metal machine, I needed the most lightweight solution and luckily without the need a ton of features.
